title: Can potential energy be transferred into other energy except kinetic energy? - Quora

response.answer_text: Well, transfer would not be the correct term. Potential energy does not actually change into another kind or type of energy. Both potential and kinetic energy are the same energy. Being potential or kinetic simply means the energy is at different states. Potential energy is energy, although in motion, that is at rest within a body or a finite region or space. In this state the energy has the potential to become more active to do work, either within its space or beyond. Potential that becomes more active, agitated or even projected is in these states called kinetic energy. The energy is not transferred it just changes states. Now, a particular potential energy can be projected as kinetic energy upon another potential form of energy that would then transfer at least some of its kinetic energy to the other. Kinetic energy is energy the was at rest motion within a body, region or space, that has become more active, agitated or even projected as work or actively doing something within or outside its potent state.

Thank you Istisk Hossain for A2A How do we define potential energy: It is energy possessed by a body by virtue of its position, stresses within itself, electric charge, and other factors. We have included gravitational, mechanical, electrical, nuclear and chemical. First three kind are convertible into kinetic energy, where potential energy is also understood as capacity to do work. Nuclear potential energy is the potential energy of the particles such as protons and neutrons that are present inside the nucleus of an atom. Nuclear fission, nuclear fusion, and nuclear decay are processes through which this kind of energy gets converted into kinetic, heat and light energy. Chemical potential energy is stored in the bonds of atoms and molecules. The chemical potential energy gets released often in the form of heat when the bonds between the atoms are broken. If you are referring to gravitational potential energy, then no. To do anything at all with that energy (to reduce the amount of gravitational potential energy) you have to let the object fall in the gravitational field. That necessitates conversion to kinetic energy. So that’s a first step. If you are speaking of more general forms of “potential energy,” such as the energy of rest mass, then yes - matter/anti-matter annihilation will convert the energy directly to photos - electromagnetic energy.

As the question suggests the most common form of energy transformation is from potential energy to kinetic energy. There are machines that turn potential energy into potential energy of a different type. These would include hydro-electric dams, gas power plants, nuclear power plants and radioisotope generators. However, to do this they all have to turn the potential energy into kinetic energy first then back into potential energy of a different type. The kinetic energy of a photon can be transfered to the mass energy of a e+e- pair via the process of pain -> conversion. gamma -> e+e- (plus a little tickle to conserve momentum). The kinetic energy of light particles can be come the mass energy of other heavier particles when they collide with each other. e+e- → mu+mu- is a pretty common reaction in collides. It’s rate is calculable in QED and it’s easy to distinguish from other processes. It’s often used to monitor the luminosity of the beams — a function of how many e’s there are and how well they are focused at the collision point.

In 1802 Thomas Young introduced the term energy to stand for what we now call kinetic energy. 50 years later Rankine and others began to use the term potential for any energy which is not kinetic; so total energy=potential energy+kinetic energy by definition.
